text:
This is Mattias Björnmalm, and he’s doing
chemistry at about 50 meters per second.

The tube he’s clutching contains a sample
of metal-organic frameworks in the process
of crystallizing.

Björnmalm was part of a group of scientists
investigating whether low-gravity conditions

would affect the size of the MOF crystals,
potentially giving researchers a new tool
to control MOF properties.

They designed special injectors that allowed
Björnmalm to mix two solutions just before
jumping out of the plane.

Björnmalm: We’re going to mix these two
solutions and it’s going to form MOF crystals.

Aside from wanting to commemorate the experience,
the scientists recorded the experiment so

they could show others precisely how it was
done.
Björnmalm: It is very fun to do.

But it’s also one of these things, which
we thought a lot about, how to convey how
you actually did something.

Björnmalm is one of a growing number of chemists
using action cameras like GoPros, cell phone

cameras, and other inexpensive video equipment
to record step-by-step experimental procedures.

Chemists are taking this footage to prevent
errors when others try to reproduce experiments
and to prevent unsafe practices.

Strapping a camera to yourself as you jump
out of a plane is definitely on the extreme

end of things, but these recordings are proving
to be useful communication tools in labs and
in journal articles.

Back on Earth, Björnmalm and his colleagues
also capture experimental procedures with
a small action camera.

This helps communicate information that might
get lost in written instructions, especially

when it comes to complicated, multistep processes,
Björnmalm says.

For researchers who are new to a procedure,
videos may offer useful tricks and safe techniques
that more expert handlers take for granted.

Björnmalm: These kinds of information can
be very hard to convey on a piece of paper
by writing down.

In a video you can see how someone takes something
and moves it into another beaker or moves
it into another reaction vessel.

Scientific journals are beginning to embrace
videos too.

The journal Chemistry of Materials, for example,
launched a new article type in early 2017

that requires nuanced, detailed descriptions
of how to synthesize substances and encourages
videos.

The goal is to help prevent reproducibility
issues that arise from minor differences in

interpretation of written instructions, says
the journal’s editor in chief, Jillian Buriak.

Of course, parameters like where you bought
your reagents or what settings you gave your
instrument remain easier to convey on paper.

But video can help complete the picture by
showing details authors might otherwise overlook
when writing articles.
Buriak: The devil is in the details.

Very subtle things can have a profound effect
on the outcome of a reaction, but they’re

not described because someone doesn’t think
that they’re important.

There's no excuse anymore because everyone's
carrying around a really good video camera.

Although the barrier to creating videos may
be low, Buriak thinks that giving them a central

role in scientific publishing will be a challenge,
working against centuries of text-dominated
history.

The videos available today can be hard to
find, relegated to supporting information

sections and often appearing in inconsistent
formats.

The journal eLife, which focuses on life sciences
and biomedical research, is among those trying
to better showcase videos.

eLife’s head of product, Giuliano Maciocci,
says he believes that for readers to reap

the full benefit of videos, they need to be
as easy to engage with as the figures and
text of an article.

So the journal embeds videos directly within
its articles and developed technical infrastructure

that would accommodate the variety of videos
authors submitted.

Videos are also helping chemists in both research
and teaching labs.

At Central New Mexico Community College, chemistry
instructor Clarissa Sorensen-Unruh uses video

to make instruments more accessible to a staff
that includes several part-timers.

Sorensen-Unruh: I’m going to put my sample
right on here.

Frequent turnover and scheduling conflicts
made it difficult to formally train everyone
on the equipment.

Sorensen-Unruh: Between all those moving pieces
and everything changing every semester, something
has to give.

It is, I think, imperative to give as many
tools and as much preparation as possible
in as many different ways as we can.

In Anna Larsen’s chemistry lab at Ithaca
College, students themselves make videos showing

the proper use of equipment from a chemist’s-eye
view.

Larsen says the perspective helps students
relate to what’s happening on-screen.

Sometimes they even work with film students
at the college to clearly communicate the

procedures, exposing a new audience to what
goes on inside the lab.

Larsen: Oftentimes we see students kind of
scared of anything that touches on chemistry.

I believe the more outreach we can get to
so-called lay audience, the better off everyone
will be.

Back at Imperial College, Mattias Björnmalm
is also building an inventory of training

videos for instruments and procedures to complement
in-person training for his group members,

a practice he started with coworkers previously
at the University of Melbourne.

Björnmalm: We’re not trying to make the
next blockbuster movie where everything needs
to be perfect.

The key is trying to convey things that we’re
all passionate about and that we want to do
well.
Björnmalm: To, to separate them?
Yeah, yeah.

Björnmalm says he sees video as a way to
share that passion not only with his colleagues

and collaborators but also with communities
outside the lab, and even outside the scientific community

Björnmalm: I think it can be very helpful
to see what we do when we say we are in the

lab and we’re working on a new research
project, that it’s a lot less of a black

box, that researchers go away somewhere, do
things, and come back with results.
It’s a lot more of a process.

Do you make videos a regular part of your
lab work?
Share your favorite video with us!

You can post a link in the comments or email
us here.
